Rationale
Change to staffing. This is a recently developed module and the staffing has now been finalised.

LIFE399
Notes
This module is taught to students in both the Department of Psychology and the School of Biosciences. Teaching and learning are integrated for both groups and the module content and assessment is identical for each cohort. Any proposed changes have been requested by both departments and will only be implemented upon is approval is jointly agreed.

The key changes for 399 for academic year 25/26 are outlined below:

1. Module requirements – reduce the requirement for students to secure 140 hours of work based experience to 70 hours.

The current requirement of 140 hours of work based experience, combined with 70 hours of self directed learning and 10–12 hours of contact teaching, means that the current hours associated with 399 exceed the recommended 150 hours. Reducing the work based experience requirement to 70 hours, while keeping the same hours of self directed and contact teaching, aligns with the time commitment to 150 hours – what is expected for a 15 credit module.
The reduction in hours also promotes inclusivity within the module, aligning with the core values of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, which recognises potential barriers to learning and aims to ensure that all students can access the curriculum regardless of their circumstances. By reducing the requirement to 70 hours, we enhance accessibility for students from underrepresented backgrounds. Given the current cost of living crisis, many students are required to balance part-time work and other responsibilities, this reduction helps eliminate barriers related to the time they are able to commit to extra curricula activities such as work based experience. The existing requirement of 140 hours equates to approximately four weeks of full-time work, which is unmanageable for students balancing various commitments and unreasonable for those engaged in unpaid work. There is an established link between completing work experience and boosting student confidence and institutional and wider sector data shows that gaining work experience significantly enhances students' ability to achieve positive outcomes after graduation. Therefore, it is in everyone's best interest to support as many students as possible in securing and making the most of these experiences.

Further rationale for this reduction is to align with authentic industry and institutional practices. Most organisations offer work based experiences that typically fall under 140 hours. For example, research placements often last two weeks, meaning that students who secure these opportunities fall short of the 140 hour requirement for the module. In addition, the availability of 140-hour experiences are limited, making it extremely competitive for students to secure. Most students who initially express interest in the module have to withdraw as they are not able to meet the 140 hour requirement. It is well recognised by industry and institutions that a 70 hour work based experience provides sufficient time for students to take on responsibility to develop a meaningful experience and graduate level skill development.

Overall, the current 140 hour requirement is non inclusive, unnecessary and prevents many students from participating in the module. It is important to note that while the requirement will be 70 hours, this is a minimum and students who are able to complete additional hours can still do so and are not restricted to 70 hours.


2. Module requirements – include Virtual Work Based Experiences created by Careers and Employability and partner organisations as an approved form of Work Based Experience
The introduction of Virtual Work Based Experiences aims to enhance the inclusivity of the module by addressing challenges related to competition, limited availability and the need for greater flexibility than traditional work placements offer.
The VWBEs are designed to maintain the same quality of skill development as in person work based experience. They are created and reviewed in collaboration with Careers and Employability and industry experts, such as the Senior User Experience team at The Very Group and the Senior Medical Communications team at IPG Health Med Comms. These experiences are structured to provide skill development that aligns with the requirements for entering graduate level roles and both IPG and TVG view this experience as highly relevant for preparing students for positions in the sector. Although they are self directed and virtual, they are designed to be engaging, interactive and provide a higher level of responsibility than is offered in many in person experiences. The blended nature of the VWBE mean that students are conducting real world research and tackling authentic project briefs.
The lack of interaction offered by a virtual work based experience is mitigated through timetabled drop in session and online interactions with the employers involved.
The experiences are structured to match that of an in person experience and include inductions and onboarding training that is designed by talent development professionals who manage the same processes for in person experiences. The scaffolded design of the experience ensures that self reflective feedback is provided throughout to ensure student progress through the experience correctly.
These experiences support our inclusivity goals, aligning with the emphasis on inclusivity within the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Considering our diverse student demographic and the increasing demand for work experience from employers, offering this alternative is essential to ensure that all students have access to meaningful work-based experiences and meeting the strategic objectives of 2031, to develop confident graduate able to successfully compete in the graduate labour market.
Importantly, VWBEs complement in person experiences rather than replace them. They are an additional option for students who are unable to secure traditional placements. However, for some students, the VWBEs may better prepare them for their career goals than in person experiences, making them a preferred choice.
The VWBEs have been evaluated from both student and employer perspectives and have been recognised as a high quality form of work based experience. They immerse students in a specific sector, facilitate the development of graduate level skills and effectively meet the learning objectives of this module.
3. Updates to assessment – removal of the existing consultancy report and introduction of 100% reflective portfolio
The assessment to become 100% Reflective Portfolio with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be one deadline for the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered submission dates. Students will be evaluated on their personal development throughout the module, using reflections and evidence of their progress. This will include:
Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%
Post-experience Skills Reflection – 40%
Career Management – 50%
Further details on the assessment strategy can be found under the relevant section.
4. Updates to the Learning Outcomes to reflect the above changes
Learning objectives related to designing and justifying workplace recommendations and evaluating current work based experience practices have been removed. These objectives were constructively aligned with the Consultancy Report, for which removal has been requested.
To better reflect the updated assessment approach, the below learning outcomes have been introduced:
LO2   Recognise, express, and evidence skillset with a view to writing future job and postgraduate study applications.
*note this LO has been updated in the this LIFE399CM, but submitted as a comment to the curriculum board of LIFE399 Psych as a note
LO3Critically analyse the specific requirements and expectations of the labour market in a chosen sector or field of interest through targeted research.

5. General updates to language throughout
The term "placement" has been updated to "work based experience" to better capture the range of experiences approved under the current version of 399. For example, volunteering qualifies as a work based experience that meets the learning objectives and effectively supports skill development required. Many students choose volunteering as their preferred form of work based experience, the term "placement" is too specific and does not accurately capture volunteering and other types of work based experiences included in the module.

Overview

Overview
This module allows students to undertake a work-based experience (minimum of 70 hours) that will be undertaken during the summer-break between Year 2 and Year 3. For the purpose of this module, work- based experience is broad and captures any experience that allows students to develop professional skills aligned to their personal career goals and has been approved by the module team. Work based experience can include, but is not limited to; internships, placements, lab placements, research placements, volunteering, summer schools and University of Liverpool approved Virtual Work Based Experiences. The teaching associated with this module supports students to identify and articulate the skills gained from their experiences, including those often overlooked to take positive career management actions.

The module will be divided into three phases. A pre-experience phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the work based experience, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual work-based experience and a final post-experience phase, consisting of seminars for reflection and preparation to final assessment. Module assessments are highly authentic and include a skill audit and reflective log to be completed before, during and after the practical work based experience and CV based on the work based experience of the individual student.

All students will benefit from a series of skills training sessions in semester 2 of year 2 (pre-experience phase), delivered by Careers & Employability (C&E). They will be encouraged to seek a ‘traditional’ work based experience that will help them develop employability skills, in any professional sector that aligns to their career goals. If students are successful in obtaining a work based experience, this will be undertaken in the summer between years 2 and 3 (core applied phase).

If students are not successful in obtaining, or do not wish to undertake a ‘traditional’ work based experiences, they can opt to engage in one of the virtual work based experiences created by Careers and Employability in collaboration with a partner employer. These too will be completed over the summer period. Students who opt for the virtual work based experience will engaging will take a blended approach to work based experience. They will also develop sector specific skills through taking ownership of an authentic project within the sector.

In semester 1 of year 3, students will attend in person seminars (post-experience phase), incorporating group work and skills reflection which will again delivered by C&E. All students, regardless of which work based experience activity they undertake, will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a work based experience external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s work based experience site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the work based experience. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to prepare students for a successful career post-graduation. The module aims to give students the opportunity to further develop their skills and professional behaviours, reflect on them and evidence them for future employment/ research.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module allows students to undertake a work-based experience, either virtually or in person, during the summer period between Year 2 and Year 3. Unless completing one of the University of Liverpool approved Virtual Work Based Experience, students will be required to find and secure their own work-based experience, which must be approved by the module leader beforehand. Work based experience will be a minimum of 70 hours of work experience (approximately 2 weeks of full-time work).

Early in Year 2, there will be an introductory event to present the module and advise students on how to search for work-based experience opportunities. This session will be available to all students (including those not wishing to enrol in the module). Students will be encouraged to search for work-based experiences during their second year, with the support of Academic Advisers and Careers and Employability. Additional seminar activities will take place in Semester 2 of Year 2 to help prepare students for their work based experience. Students will not have a confirmed place on the module until they have secured a 70 hour work based experience that is approved by the module teaching team. They must then complete and fulfil the requirements of the work based module over the summer period in order to progress with the module. When selecting 399 as a final year module choice, students will be required to select an ‘insurance’ module which will replace 399 should they not fulfil the requirements for whatever reason.
Further taught sessions in early Semester 1 of Year 3 will include seminars on relevant employability theories and research, taking positive career management action, attendance at a graduate level assessment centre, networking with employers, skills articulation and reflective group sessions on work based experiences.

Incorporating a work based experience provides an opportunity for students to improve skills that are particularly sought after by employers and postgraduate study providers. The module teaching will support students to better recognise, evidence and articulate their skillset to support their future career goals. The module will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-experience phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the work based experience, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual work based expereince, and a final post-experience phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and including in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-experience seminars:
-Seminars focused on preparing for the work based experience work, including:
-Introduction to the module
-Employer networking fair providing students with the opportunity to network with employers offering work based experience.
-Researching potential employers and securing a work based experience, including CV advice and preparing for the application process
-Getting the most from the work based experience: how to be reflective and identify employability skills to develop
-Health and Safety, professional conduct, and workplace expectations
-Assessment guidelines: How to complete reflective logs; structure and content of the final reflective portfolio
-Learning and conduct agreement: setting expectations for the work based experience

Core applied phase:
- Work based experience: Students will undertake an approved employment work based experience (in person or virtual work-based experience) lasting approximately 70 hours of work experience.
- The exact nature and format of the work based experience will vary, but all will ensure students meet the module's learning outcomes.

Post-experience activity:
-Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
-Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
-Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
- Guidance for writing the final portfolio based on reflective practice and theories discussed during the module
- Guidance on CVs and supporting statements
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-experience seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ work based experience, prepare them for work based experience, introduce them to the employability theory and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the work based experience itself, which will either be a traditional work based experience or a University of Liverpool Careers and Employability virtual work based experience. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first two years of their studies. Post-experience seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-experience sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks and their work based experience. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and work based experience engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with work based experience activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

Further details on teaching and learning associated with each phase is below.
________________________________________
Pre-Experience Seminar (4 hours)
Description:
Pre-experience seminars provide essential instructions and preparation for a safe and successful work based experience. They include:
- Introduction to the module (Year 2, Semester 1: one seminar early in the semester to introduce the module to the entire Year 2 cohort).
- Researching prospective employers (Year 2, Semester 1: seminars from this point onwards are for students undertaking the module).
- The application process, including CV and interview preparation (Year 2, Semester 1).
- Review of the work based experience to ensure learning objectives and assessment requirements are met, including Health & Safety (Year 2, Semester 2).
- Assessment guidance: Completing reflective logs and initial completion of a skills audit (Year 2, Semester 2).
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Student attendance at pre-experience seminars will be recorded to ensure engagement with the preparatory process.
________________________________________
Work Based Experience (70 hours)
Description:
Students will engage in either an in-person or virtual work based experience, depending on availability and individual circumstances. The duration is expected to be approximately 70 hours, though this the minimum and students who are able and wanting to complete additional hours may do so.
- Students are required to complete a skills audit and reflective log throughout their work based experience, documenting their experiences and reflecting on the development of key employability skills.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Effective engagement with the experience will be monitored through the completion of the weekly skills audit and reflective logs, ensuring continuous reflection and skill development.
________________________________________
Post- experience seminars (10 hours)
Description:
Post-experience seminars focus on reflection and transfer practical experience into positive career management action.
These sessions will include:
- Individual and group discussions to share experiences
- Support in identifying, articulating and applying developed skills to future career goals
- Graduate assessment centre activities, both independent and collaborative
- Guidance on positive career management steps: networking, gap analysis, sector-specific research and CV/ application drafting

Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Attendance at post-experience seminars will be recorded to ensure students are actively engaging in the reflective process and final assessment preparation.
________________________________________
Self-Directed Learning (70 hours)
Description:
In addition to the time spent on work based experience, students are expected to engage in approximately 70 hours of self-directed learning. This includes:
- Searching for work based experience opportunities independently.
- Completing the work based experience Registration Form (PRF), which includes several sub-forms (e.g., Health & Safety Awareness, Risk Assessment, DBS check, Travel Insurance, Experience Provider H&S Assessment, Professional Etiquette, Functional Declaration).
- Self reflective tasks completed during and following completion of the work-based experience
- Research-based tasks that are integrated within the portfolio, such as analysing labour market demands to create an effective career management plan, researching organisations before attending graduate level assessment centres and engaging in self-assessment and opportunity awareness tasks aligned with career goals. These tasks will support the completion of career management activities in the portfolio, such as creating a CV.

NOTE: In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy is informed and guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The assessment for this module will consist of a 100% Reflective Portfolio, with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be a single final deadline for submission the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered completion dates to ensure continuous development and reflection throughout the module. Students will be evaluated based on their personal growth and development during the module, supported by reflections and evidence of progress.

Details of the assessment breakdown:
1. Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%
- Students will complete a skills audit at the beginning of the module, detailing their initial skill level and identifying key areas for development. (500 words)

2. Peri and post-experience Skills Reflection – 40%
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their experience, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory (2 x 300 words)
- A final skills audit, completed at the end of the module, that demonstrates the student’s progress throughout the experience and how this has prepared them for their future career (500 words)
- A reflective blog or video (750 words or 3 minutes – Awaiting guidance from CIE on this ), where students choose the format to highlight their development and skills after completing their work experience.

3. Career Management – 50%
- A CV and supporting statement tailored to a job or postgraduate opportunity of the student’s choice (~500 words)
- Networking/ informational interview reflection- students will identify a professional whose career aligns with their own aspirations. They will then plan to reach out to request an informational interview to learn more about the sector. Following the interaction students will submit a brief reflection on the key takeaways (300 words)
- A final skills mapping and gap analysis that identifies current skills, gaps, and future steps for development based on career aspirations (300 words)
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre with a reflection on their individual and collaborative experience at the Graduate Assessment Centre, focusing on career management and employability skills (300 words)
________________________________________
Resit Policy:
Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Version Description:
Changes for 399 for academic year 25/26

Module requirements

Reduce the requirement for students to secure 140 hours of work based experience to 70 hours.

Assessment

The assessment to become 100% Reflective Portfolio with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be one deadline for the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered submission dates. Students will be evaluated on their personal development throughout the module, using reflections and evidence of their progress. This will include:

Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%

A skills audit at the beginning of the module showing their initial skill level and areas for development.

Post-experience Skills Reflection – 50%

A skills audit at the end of the module demonstrating their progress.
Formative reflective logs that track their skills and knowledge development throughout their work-based experience.
A reflective blog or video (750 words or 3 minutes) after completing their work experience, where they can choose the format to highlight their development and skills.

Career Management – 40%

A CV and supporting statement tailored to a job or postgraduate opportunity of their choice.
A reflection on their collaborative and individual experience at the Graduate Assessment Centre.

LIFE399
Notes
This module is taught to students in both the Department of Psychology and the School of Biosciences. Teaching and learning are integrated for both groups and the module content and assessment is identical for each cohort. Any proposed changes have been requested by both departments and will only be implemented upon is approval is jointly agreed.

The key changes for 399 for academic year 25/26 are outlined below:

1. Module requirements – reduce the requirement for students to secure 140 hours of work based experience to 70 hours.

The current requirement of 140 hours of work based experience, combined with 70 hours of self directed learning and 10–12 hours of contact teaching, means that the current hours associated with 399 exceed the recommended 150 hours. Reducing the work based experience requirement to 70 hours, while keeping the same hours of self directed and contact teaching, aligns with the time commitment to 150 hours – what is expected for a 15 credit module.
The reduction in hours also promotes inclusivity within the module, aligning with the core values of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, which recognises potential barriers to learning and aims to ensure that all students can access the curriculum regardless of their circumstances. By reducing the requirement to 70 hours, we enhance accessibility for students from underrepresented backgrounds. Given the current cost of living crisis, many students are required to balance part-time work and other responsibilities, this reduction helps eliminate barriers related to the time they are able to commit to extra curricula activities such as work based experience. The existing requirement of 140 hours equates to approximately four weeks of full-time work, which is unmanageable for students balancing various commitments and unreasonable for those engaged in unpaid work. There is an established link between completing work experience and boosting student confidence and institutional and wider sector data shows that gaining work experience significantly enhances students' ability to achieve positive outcomes after graduation. Therefore, it is in everyone's best interest to support as many students as possible in securing and making the most of these experiences.

Further rationale for this reduction is to align with authentic industry and institutional practices. Most organisations offer work based experiences that typically fall under 140 hours. For example, research placements often last two weeks, meaning that students who secure these opportunities fall short of the 140 hour requirement for the module. In addition, the availability of 140-hour experiences are limited, making it extremely competitive for students to secure. Most students who initially express interest in the module have to withdraw as they are not able to meet the 140 hour requirement. It is well recognised by industry and institutions that a 70 hour work based experience provides sufficient time for students to take on responsibility to develop a meaningful experience and graduate level skill development.

Overall, the current 140 hour requirement is non inclusive, unnecessary and prevents many students from participating in the module. It is important to note that while the requirement will be 70 hours, this is a minimum and students who are able to complete additional hours can still do so and are not restricted to 70 hours.


2. Module requirements – include Virtual Work Based Experiences created by Careers and Employability and partner organisations as an approved form of Work Based Experience
The introduction of Virtual Work Based Experiences aims to enhance the inclusivity of the module by addressing challenges related to competition, limited availability and the need for greater flexibility than traditional work placements offer.
The VWBEs are designed to maintain the same quality of skill development as in person work based experience. They are created and reviewed in collaboration with Careers and Employability and industry experts, such as the Senior User Experience team at The Very Group and the Senior Medical Communications team at IPG Health Med Comms. These experiences are structured to provide skill development that aligns with the requirements for entering graduate level roles and both IPG and TVG view this experience as highly relevant for preparing students for positions in the sector. Although they are self directed and virtual, they are designed to be engaging, interactive and provide a higher level of responsibility than is offered in many in person experiences. The blended nature of the VWBE mean that students are conducting real world research and tackling authentic project briefs.
The lack of interaction offered by a virtual work based experience is mitigated through timetabled drop in session and online interactions with the employers involved.
The experiences are structured to match that of an in person experience and include inductions and onboarding training that is designed by talent development professionals who manage the same processes for in person experiences. The scaffolded design of the experience ensures that self reflective feedback is provided throughout to ensure student progress through the experience correctly.
These experiences support our inclusivity goals, aligning with the emphasis on inclusivity within the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Considering our diverse student demographic and the increasing demand for work experience from employers, offering this alternative is essential to ensure that all students have access to meaningful work-based experiences and meeting the strategic objectives of 2031, to develop confident graduate able to successfully compete in the graduate labour market.
Importantly, VWBEs complement in person experiences rather than replace them. They are an additional option for students who are unable to secure traditional placements. However, for some students, the VWBEs may better prepare them for their career goals than in person experiences, making them a preferred choice.
The VWBEs have been evaluated from both student and employer perspectives and have been recognised as a high quality form of work based experience. They immerse students in a specific sector, facilitate the development of graduate level skills and effectively meet the learning objectives of this module.
3. Updates to assessment – removal of the existing consultancy report and introduction of 100% reflective portfolio
The assessment to become 100% Reflective Portfolio with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be one deadline for the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered submission dates. Students will be evaluated on their personal development throughout the module, using reflections and evidence of their progress. This will include:
Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%
Post-experience Skills Reflection – 40%
Career Management – 50%
Further details on the assessment strategy can be found under the relevant section.
4. Updates to the Learning Outcomes to reflect the above changes
Learning objectives related to designing and justifying workplace recommendations and evaluating current work based experience practices have been removed. These objectives were constructively aligned with the Consultancy Report, for which removal has been requested.
To better reflect the updated assessment approach, the below learning outcomes have been introduced:
LO2   Recognise, express, and evidence skillset with a view to writing future job and postgraduate study applications.
*note this LO has been updated in the this LIFE399CM, but submitted as a comment to the curriculum board of LIFE399 Psych as a note
LO3Critically analyse the specific requirements and expectations of the labour market in a chosen sector or field of interest through targeted research.

5. General updates to language throughout
The term "placement" has been updated to "work based experience" to better capture the range of experiences approved under the current version of 399. For example, volunteering qualifies as a work based experience that meets the learning objectives and effectively supports skill development required. Many students choose volunteering as their preferred form of work based experience, the term "placement" is too specific and does not accurately capture volunteering and other types of work based experiences included in the module.

Overview

Overview
This module allows students to undertake a work-based experience (minimum of 70 hours) that will be undertaken during the summer-break between Year 2 and Year 3. For the purpose of this module, work- based experience is broad and captures any experience that allows students to develop professional skills aligned to their personal career goals and has been approved by the module team. Work based experience can include, but is not limited to; internships, placements, lab placements, research placements, volunteering, summer schools and University of Liverpool approved Virtual Work Based Experiences. The teaching associated with this module supports students to identify and articulate the skills gained from their experiences, including those often overlooked to take positive career management actions.

The module will be divided into three phases. A pre-experience phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the work based experience, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual work-based experience and a final post-experience phase, consisting of seminars for reflection and preparation to final assessment. Module assessments are highly authentic and include a skill audit and reflective log to be completed before, during and after the practical work based experience and CV based on the work based experience of the individual student.

All students will benefit from a series of skills training sessions in semester 2 of year 2 (pre-experience phase), delivered by Careers & Employability (C&E). They will be encouraged to seek a ‘traditional’ work based experience that will help them develop employability skills, in any professional sector that aligns to their career goals. If students are successful in obtaining a work based experience, this will be undertaken in the summer between years 2 and 3 (core applied phase).

If students are not successful in obtaining, or do not wish to undertake a ‘traditional’ work based experiences, they can opt to engage in one of the virtual work based experiences created by Careers and Employability in collaboration with a partner employer. These too will be completed over the summer period. Students who opt for the virtual work based experience will engaging will take a blended approach to work based experience. They will also develop sector specific skills through taking ownership of an authentic project within the sector.

In semester 1 of year 3, students will attend in person seminars (post-experience phase), incorporating group work and skills reflection which will again delivered by C&E. All students, regardless of which work based experience activity they undertake, will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a work based experience external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s work based experience site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the work based experience. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to prepare students for a successful career post-graduation. The module aims to give students the opportunity to further develop their skills and professional behaviours, reflect on them and evidence them for future employment/ research.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module allows students to undertake a work-based experience, either virtually or in person, during the summer period between Year 2 and Year 3. Unless completing one of the University of Liverpool approved Virtual Work Based Experience, students will be required to find and secure their own work-based experience, which must be approved by the module leader beforehand. Work based experience will be a minimum of 70 hours of work experience (approximately 2 weeks of full-time work).

Early in Year 2, there will be an introductory event to present the module and advise students on how to search for work-based experience opportunities. This session will be available to all students (including those not wishing to enrol in the module). Students will be encouraged to search for work-based experiences during their second year, with the support of Academic Advisers and Careers and Employability. Additional seminar activities will take place in Semester 2 of Year 2 to help prepare students for their work based experience. Students will not have a confirmed place on the module until they have secured a 70 hour work based experience that is approved by the module teaching team. They must then complete and fulfil the requirements of the work based module over the summer period in order to progress with the module. When selecting 399 as a final year module choice, students will be required to select an ‘insurance’ module which will replace 399 should they not fulfil the requirements for whatever reason.
Further taught sessions in early Semester 1 of Year 3 will include seminars on relevant employability theories and research, taking positive career management action, attendance at a graduate level assessment centre, networking with employers, skills articulation and reflective group sessions on work based experiences.

Incorporating a work based experience provides an opportunity for students to improve skills that are particularly sought after by employers and postgraduate study providers. The module teaching will support students to better recognise, evidence and articulate their skillset to support their future career goals. The module will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-experience phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the work based experience, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual work based expereince, and a final post-experience phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and including in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-experience seminars:
-Seminars focused on preparing for the work based experience work, including:
-Introduction to the module
-Employer networking fair providing students with the opportunity to network with employers offering work based experience.
-Researching potential employers and securing a work based experience, including CV advice and preparing for the application process
-Getting the most from the work based experience: how to be reflective and identify employability skills to develop
-Health and Safety, professional conduct, and workplace expectations
-Assessment guidelines: How to complete reflective logs; structure and content of the final reflective portfolio
-Learning and conduct agreement: setting expectations for the work based experience

Core applied phase:
- Work based experience: Students will undertake an approved employment work based experience (in person or virtual work-based experience) lasting approximately 70 hours of work experience.
- The exact nature and format of the work based experience will vary, but all will ensure students meet the module's learning outcomes.

Post-experience activity:
-Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
-Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
-Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
- Guidance for writing the final portfolio based on reflective practice and theories discussed during the module
- Guidance on CVs and supporting statements
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-experience seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ work based experience, prepare them for work based experience, introduce them to the employability theory and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the work based experience itself, which will either be a traditional work based experience or a University of Liverpool Careers and Employability virtual work based experience. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first two years of their studies. Post-experience seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-experience sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks and their work based experience. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and work based experience engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with work based experience activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

Further details on teaching and learning associated with each phase is below.
________________________________________
Pre-Experience Seminar (4 hours)
Description:
Pre-experience seminars provide essential instructions and preparation for a safe and successful work based experience. They include:
- Introduction to the module (Year 2, Semester 1: one seminar early in the semester to introduce the module to the entire Year 2 cohort).
- Researching prospective employers (Year 2, Semester 1: seminars from this point onwards are for students undertaking the module).
- The application process, including CV and interview preparation (Year 2, Semester 1).
- Review of the work based experience to ensure learning objectives and assessment requirements are met, including Health & Safety (Year 2, Semester 2).
- Assessment guidance: Completing reflective logs and initial completion of a skills audit (Year 2, Semester 2).
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Student attendance at pre-experience seminars will be recorded to ensure engagement with the preparatory process.
________________________________________
Work Based Experience (70 hours)
Description:
Students will engage in either an in-person or virtual work based experience, depending on availability and individual circumstances. The duration is expected to be approximately 70 hours, though this the minimum and students who are able and wanting to complete additional hours may do so.
- Students are required to complete a skills audit and reflective log throughout their work based experience, documenting their experiences and reflecting on the development of key employability skills.
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Effective engagement with the experience will be monitored through the completion of the weekly skills audit and reflective logs, ensuring continuous reflection and skill development.
________________________________________
Post- experience seminars (10 hours)
Description:
Post-experience seminars focus on reflection and transfer practical experience into positive career management action.
These sessions will include:
- Individual and group discussions to share experiences
- Support in identifying, articulating and applying developed skills to future career goals
- Graduate assessment centre activities, both independent and collaborative
- Guidance on positive career management steps: networking, gap analysis, sector-specific research and CV/ application drafting

Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Attendance at post-experience seminars will be recorded to ensure students are actively engaging in the reflective process and final assessment preparation.
________________________________________
Self-Directed Learning (70 hours)
Description:
In addition to the time spent on work based experience, students are expected to engage in approximately 70 hours of self-directed learning. This includes:
- Searching for work based experience opportunities independently.
- Completing the work based experience Registration Form (PRF), which includes several sub-forms (e.g., Health & Safety Awareness, Risk Assessment, DBS check, Travel Insurance, Experience Provider H&S Assessment, Professional Etiquette, Functional Declaration).
- Self reflective tasks completed during and following completion of the work-based experience
- Research-based tasks that are integrated within the portfolio, such as analysing labour market demands to create an effective career management plan, researching organisations before attending graduate level assessment centres and engaging in self-assessment and opportunity awareness tasks aligned with career goals. These tasks will support the completion of career management activities in the portfolio, such as creating a CV.

NOTE: In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy is informed and guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The assessment for this module will consist of a 100% Reflective Portfolio, with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be a single final deadline for submission the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered completion dates to ensure continuous development and reflection throughout the module. Students will be evaluated based on their personal growth and development during the module, supported by reflections and evidence of progress.

Details of the assessment breakdown:
1. Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%
- Students will complete a skills audit at the beginning of the module, detailing their initial skill level and identifying key areas for development. (500 words)

2. Peri and post-experience Skills Reflection – 40%
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their experience, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory (2 x 300 words)
- A final skills audit, completed at the end of the module, that demonstrates the student’s progress throughout the experience and how this has prepared them for their future career (500 words)
- A reflective blog or video (750 words or 3 minutes – Awaiting guidance from CIE on this ), where students choose the format to highlight their development and skills after completing their work experience.

3. Career Management – 50%
- A CV and supporting statement tailored to a job or postgraduate opportunity of the student’s choice (~500 words)
- Networking/ informational interview reflection- students will identify a professional whose career aligns with their own aspirations. They will then plan to reach out to request an informational interview to learn more about the sector. Following the interaction students will submit a brief reflection on the key takeaways (300 words)
- A final skills mapping and gap analysis that identifies current skills, gaps, and future steps for development based on career aspirations (300 words)
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre with a reflection on their individual and collaborative experience at the Graduate Assessment Centre, focusing on career management and employability skills (300 words)
________________________________________
Resit Policy:
Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Rudi Verspoor  About 10 months ago  |  View Original
Submitted the module for approval
Modification of this module is complete.

These changes have been submitted in combination with Psych399. So should be considered jointly by FASQ if possible.

Version Description:
Changes for 399 for academic year 25/26

Module requirements

Reduce the requirement for students to secure 140 hours of work based experience to 70 hours.

Assessment

The assessment to become 100% Reflective Portfolio with credit assigned to specific tasks within the digital portfolio. There will be one deadline for the portfolio, but specific tasks will have staggered submission dates. Students will be evaluated on their personal development throughout the module, using reflections and evidence of their progress. This will include:

Pre-experience Skills Reflection and Goal Setting – 10%

A skills audit at the beginning of the module showing their initial skill level and areas for development.

Post-experience Skills Reflection – 50%

A skills audit at the end of the module demonstrating their progress.
Formative reflective logs that track their skills and knowledge development throughout their work-based experience.
A reflective blog or video (750 words or 3 minutes) after completing their work experience, where they can choose the format to highlight their development and skills.

Career Management – 40%

A CV and supporting statement tailored to a job or postgraduate opportunity of their choice.
A reflection on their collaborative and individual experience at the Graduate Assessment Centre.
